Bulldog Strong,
Yolanda Brunt

Measles is a highly contagious virus that spreads through the air when an infected person
breathes, coughs or sneezes. The virus can live up to two hours in the air. Measles is so
contagious that if someone has it, nearly everyone close to that person will also get the disease unless they have been vaccinated or are immune. A person is considered immune if they have had the disease, been fully vaccinated or born before 1957.
